title: Simple Circuits
subject: Physics
objective: Understand the differences between series and parallel circuits, their properties, and real-world applications
learningOutcomes: Explain how current flows in series and parallel circuits
Compare brightness and behavior of bulbs in different circuit configurations
Identify real-world examples of series and parallel circuits
Calculate current and voltage distribution in circuits
Understand why parallel circuits are preferred in homes

theory.introduction: Electric circuits are closed loops through which electric current flows. Understanding how components can be connected is fundamental to electricity. There are two main ways to connect components: in series or in parallel.

sections.title: Series Circuits
sections.content:
In a series circuit, all components are connected in a single loop. Current flows through one component after another in sequence. Key characteristics of series circuits:

• Single path for current flow
• Same current through all components (I₁ = I₂ = I₃)
• Voltages add up across components (V_total = V₁ + V₂ + V₃)
• If one component breaks or is removed, the entire circuit stops working
• More components means more resistance and less current
• Light bulbs become progressively dimmer as more are added

Example: Old Christmas light strings where one broken bulb meant the entire string went dark
sections.importance: Series connections are used where we need components to operate in sequence or where we want the circuit to break if any component fails

sections.title: Parallel Circuits
sections.content:
In a parallel circuit, components are connected on separate branches. Current splits at junctions and can follow multiple paths. Key characteristics of parallel circuits:

• Multiple paths for current flow
• Same voltage across all components (V₁ = V₂ = V₃ = V_total)
• Currents add up at junctions (I_total = I₁ + I₂ + I₃)
• If one component breaks, others continue to work
• More branches means less total resistance and more total current
• Light bulbs stay equally bright regardless of how many are added

Example: Electrical outlets in a house - each outlet operates independently at full voltage
sections.importance: Parallel connections are used when we need components to operate independently and safely fail without affecting others

sections.title: Comparing Series and Parallel
sections.content:
Series circuits are simple but have the 'all or nothing' limitation. Parallel circuits are more complex but provide reliability. The choice depends on the application:

Series is used for:
• Simple applications where reliability isn't critical
• Dimmer switches (resistances in series reduce voltage)
• Old lighting systems
• Some battery arrangements for added voltage

Parallel is used for:
• Home electrical systems
• Modern lighting
• Battery arrangements for added capacity
• Any critical system that shouldn't fail completely
sections.importance: Understanding which configuration to use is essential for safe and effective electrical design

steps.title: Introduction and Safety
steps.description: Review circuit safety precautions and understand what you'll learn today
keyPoints: Always use low voltage (batteries, not mains electricity)
Check connections before closing the circuit
Disconnect immediately if wires become hot
Never create short circuits directly across batteries

steps.title: Gather Components
steps.description: Collect all necessary circuit components in order
keyPoints: Identify each component by its symbol
Ensure all bulbs have the same rating for fair comparison
Check that wires are in good condition

steps.title: Build Series Circuit
steps.description: Connect components in a single continuous loop
procedure: Connect the positive terminal of the battery to one end of the wire
Connect the first bulb to the wire (one terminal in, one terminal out)
Connect the second bulb to the end of the first bulb (series connection)
Connect the third bulb to the end of the second bulb
Connect the final wire from the third bulb back to the negative terminal of the battery
Add one switch in the circuit to control the entire loop
observations: Note the brightness of the bulbs
Observe that all bulbs are lit
Observe that bulbs are dimmer than they would be alone
Try removing one bulb - the entire circuit goes dark
keyPoints: All current flows through each bulb sequentially
Bulb brightness decreases as more components are added
One broken component breaks the entire circuit

steps.title: Build Parallel Circuit
procedure: Connect the positive terminal of the battery to a junction point
From this junction, create three separate paths (branches)
On each branch, connect a bulb in series with a switch
Connect the other end of each bulb back to the negative terminal junction
Ensure all branches connect back to the same point
observations: Note the brightness of the bulbs - they should be very bright
Observe that all bulbs are equally bright
Observe that bulbs are brighter than in the series circuit
Try opening one switch - other bulbs stay lit
Try removing one bulb - other bulbs stay lit
keyPoints: Each bulb gets full voltage from the battery
Bulb brightness remains constant as more branches are added
One broken component doesn't affect others

steps.title: Compare and Analyze
steps.description: Examine the differences between the two circuit types
comparisons: Compare brightness: Parallel bulbs are brighter
Compare behavior when a bulb breaks: Series stops, parallel continues
Compare voltage across components: Series divides voltage, parallel maintains voltage
Compare current flow: Series has one path, parallel has multiple paths
Compare resistance: Adding components increases series resistance, decreases parallel resistance
realWorldApplications: House wiring uses parallel circuits so each outlet works independently
Old Christmas light strings used series, modern ones often use parallel
Car headlights are parallel so both work independently
Battery backup systems use parallel for redundancy

safety.title: Circuit Safety
warnings: Never use mains electricity (wall outlet) for these experiments
Always use batteries (9V or less) as power source
Ensure no exposed wire touching other exposed wire (short circuit)
Never connect positive and negative terminals directly (short circuit)
Check for hot wires before removing components
If wires become hot, disconnect immediately
Keep circuits away from water and metal objects
Wear safety goggles if bulbs may shatter
beforeStarting: Verify the battery is appropriate voltage
Ensure all components are in good condition
duringExperiment: Never touch the components while the circuit is live
Monitor for any signs of overheating
Keep a fire extinguisher nearby as a precaution
Have an adult supervise if you're under 18

questions.question: In a series circuit, how is current distributed?

options.text: All current flows through each component in one path
options.explanation: Correct! In series circuits, there's only one path for current, so all current flows through each component.
That's a parallel circuit characteristic. In series, current follows one continuous path.
Current is the same throughout a series circuit due to conservation of charge.

questions.question: In a parallel circuit, which bulbs are brightest?

options.text: All bulbs are bright and equal
options.explanation: Correct! In parallel circuits, each component gets full voltage, so all bulbs are equally bright.
In a parallel circuit, all bulbs get the same voltage and current, so they're equally bright.

options.text: All bulbs are dimmer than in series
options.explanation: Actually, parallel bulbs are brighter than series because each gets full voltage.

questions.question: If one bulb breaks in a parallel circuit, what happens?

options.text: Other bulbs stay lit - current finds alternate paths
options.explanation: Correct! This is why parallel circuits are used in homes - one broken device doesn't affect others.
That's what happens in a series circuit. Parallel circuits have multiple paths for current.
In a parallel circuit, each branch is independent, so removing one doesn't affect others.

questions.question: Which circuit type is used in home electrical wiring?

options.explanation: Correct! Homes use parallel circuits so each outlet and device can operate independently.
Series would mean one broken circuit breaks everything - unsafe for homes.
While some components use series internally, the main house wiring is parallel.

questions.question: If you add more bulbs to a series circuit, what happens?

options.explanation: Correct! Adding more resistance (bulbs) in series reduces current and dimness increases.
That's what happens in parallel. In series, adding components increases resistance.
In a series circuit, all components either work or none work.

formulas.name: Ohm's Law
formulas.description: Voltage equals current multiplied by resistance
formulas.example: If current is 1A and resistance is 10Ω, voltage is 1 × 10 = 10V

formulas.name: Series Resistance
formulas.description: Total resistance in series is the sum of all resistances
formulas.example: If three 10Ω resistors are in series, R_total = 10 + 10 + 10 = 30Ω

formulas.name: Parallel Resistance
formulas.description: Total resistance in parallel uses the reciprocal formula
formulas.example: If three 10Ω resistors are in parallel, 1/R_total = 1/10 + 1/10 + 1/10 = 3/10, so R_total ≈ 3.3Ω

formulas.name: Series Voltage Division
formulas.equation: V₁ : V₂ : V₃ = R₁ : R₂ : R₃
formulas.description: Voltage divides proportionally to resistance in series circuits
formulas.example: A 12V battery with resistors in ratio 1:2:3 gives voltages 2V, 4V, 6V

formulas.name: Parallel Current Division
formulas.description: Current divides inversely to resistance in parallel circuits
formulas.example: A 10Ω and 20Ω resistor in parallel share current in ratio 2:1

materials.name: Battery (6V or 9V)
materials.notes: Use DC (direct current) batteries, not AC from outlets

materials.name: Light Bulbs (same rating)
materials.purpose: Load components to show circuit behavior and brightness differences

materials.name: Connecting Wires
materials.notes: Use insulated copper wire to prevent short circuits

materials.name: Switches
materials.purpose: Control individual branches in parallel or main circuit in series

materials.name: Breadboard or Circuit Board
materials.purpose: Platform to construct and organize the circuit

materials.name: Bulb Holders (optional)
materials.notes: Prevents bulbs from falling and breaking

realWorldApplications.title: Home Electrical Wiring
realWorldApplications.explanation: Your home uses parallel circuits so each outlet operates at full voltage (110V/220V). If one appliance breaks, it doesn't affect others. Each room can have its own circuit breaker.

realWorldApplications.title: Christmas Lights
realWorldApplications.explanation: Old Christmas light strings used series (one broken light meant darkness). Modern LED strings use parallel (lights stay on if one breaks). This is why modern strings are more expensive but more reliable.

realWorldApplications.title: Car Electrical System
realWorldApplications.explanation: Headlights, tail lights, radio, and other car components are parallel. This is why losing one bulb doesn't disable the entire electrical system. The battery provides the same voltage to all components.

realWorldApplications.title: Battery Arrangements
realWorldApplications.explanation: Series batteries add voltage (two 1.5V batteries = 3V). Parallel batteries add capacity (two 1000mAh batteries = 2000mAh at same voltage). Devices often use combinations of both.

realWorldApplications.title: Computer Power Supply
realWorldApplications.explanation: Internal components are mostly parallel so each can operate independently. If one component fails, it can be replaced without affecting others.

realWorldApplications.title: Audio Amplifier Speakers
realWorldApplications.explanation: Multiple speakers are often wired in series and parallel configurations to achieve desired impedance and power distribution for optimal sound quality.

commonMistakes.mistake: Thinking parallel bulbs should be dimmer
commonMistakes.correction: Parallel bulbs are brighter because each gets full voltage. Series bulbs are dimmer because voltage is shared.

commonMistakes.mistake: Confusing series with parallel in diagrams
commonMistakes.correction: Series = one loop. Parallel = multiple branches. Use the 'train track' analogy: series is one track, parallel is multiple tracks.
Never directly connect positive and negative without any component. Always have at least one resistive element in every path.

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting that parallel needs a complete circuit on each branch
commonMistakes.correction: Each parallel branch must form a complete circuit back to both terminals of the battery.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using different bulb ratings in the same circuit
commonMistakes.correction: Use identical bulbs for fair comparison. Different ratings will show different brightness independent of circuit type.

extensions.title: Mixed Circuits
extensions.description: Build a circuit that combines series and parallel elements (e.g., two bulbs in parallel, then that combination in series with another bulb). This is what real circuits often look like.

extensions.title: Variable Resistors
extensions.description: Replace one component with a rheostat or potentiometer to see how changing resistance affects brightness and current flow.

extensions.title: Ammeter and Voltmeter
extensions.description: Use meters to measure actual voltage and current at different points in the circuit. Compare series and parallel measurements.

extensions.title: Power Calculation
extensions.description: Calculate power (P = V × I) consumed by components in different configurations. Compare which arrangement uses more or less power.

extensions.title: Real Building Wiring
extensions.description: Tour your home's electrical system with an adult. Identify where main circuit breakers are, how outlets are grouped, and understand the real-world implications of circuit design.

keyTerms.definition: A closed loop through which electric current flows
The flow of electric charge, measured in Amperes (A)
The electrical potential difference, measured in Volts (V)
Opposition to current flow, measured in Ohms (Ω)
Components connected in a single path; current flows through each component sequentially
Components connected on separate branches; current can flow through multiple paths
Direct connection between positive and negative terminals, bypassing the load
Any device that uses electrical power (light bulbs, motors, resistors, etc.)
Point where current splits into multiple paths (in parallel circuits)
Device to open or close a circuit, controlling current flow

prerequisites: Knowledge of voltage and current concepts
Ability to follow diagrams and safety instructions
